Hi i know it's been a year but can you help me if you know why is it postitve instead of negative?

@jhaixxinawaj1093  Basically, you can decide what is positive yourself depending on the situation. For example you can make north and east positive while south and west negative. You can also do north and west positive while the opposites are negative. Here, he made south and west positive for simplicity .
@hmmnotsure  Thank you!!
@jhaixxinawaj1093  Just make sure you don't make both North and South positive, or both East and West positive, because that's not possible

​ @hmmnotsure  hello, I know it's been 11 months since you said your comment but if you don't mind me asking for clarification, why is it not possible to put a positive on north to south and vice versa?  I'm kind of confused, I'd be really grateful if you'd clear up my confusion, sorry for my English, it's my second language. Thank you!

@user-se9cg6hl9c  Both north and south cannot be positive. That's because they're the same line. Imagine you have an xy plane. If you start at 0 and go up to positive 3, your y value increased by +3. If you start at 0 and go down the y axis to negative 3, your y value increased by -3 (or it decreased by +3). You can't say that both moving up and down the y axis are equivalent to increasing by +3, because they're two distinct actions. That's why both North and South can't be positive. One must be "Up" and one must be "Down", which is the same as saying one must be positive and one must be negative. The same logic applies to East and West: one must be right, one must be left -> one must be positive, one must be negative. Hope this helps!
I want to know too

Velocity can change direction because it is a vector quantity that takes into account both the magnitude and direction of an object's motion. Displacement, on the other hand, is a vector quantity that only considers the change in position of an object from its initial to final position, and therefore has only one direction. When an object changes direction, its velocity vector also changes direction, even if its speed remains constant. This is because velocity is a vector quantity that takes into account both the speed and direction of an object's motion. Displacement, on the other hand, only considers the change in position of an object, and therefore has a single direction.
Well For example you have the final as -8 and then the initial as -7 Using the formula (final value - the initial value) (Xf-Xo)  It'll be  -8-(-7) =-8(-×-=+) so -8+7 =-1😊 Done

no. average velocity is wrong. it's 37.5 mph. We dont subtract the time. We only subtract the displacement between final and initial position.
I'm also kind of confused on that but displacement is basically how far you are from your starting position so from that definition, 4 miles is correct.
Displacement = Final - initial so it supposedly D= -6-10 , the answer is -16 , I confused on that  I had relied to the formula .
@Thrive2024  me too i think he made a mistake

bruh u guys completly ignored how it works. displacement = final - initial. Initial was not 10 it was 0, the car just went +10  but started at 0. Final was 4 not -6, the car just went -6 from the +10. displacement = 4 - 0, displacement = 4.
@hamed7071  can you elaborate a little more?

@mmoonchild276  We can look at it this way. If something is going to the right it's gonna be in positive. So when it travelled 10 to the right it automatically became +10 and when it travelled to the left it became -6  so we apply the formula "right + left" which would make it +10 + (-6) giving us the answer 4. I can see why people are confused at this, I was too but the final - initial is a different formula and can't be used in this unless we take 0 as initial and 4 as final (which is not something he mentioned in that 6:16 problem) so for this one either just do the right - left formula or go an extra mile and figure out the final and initial yourself. Note: neither 6 or 10 is final or initial, 0 is initial and 4 is final so 6-10 is invalid it should either be 4-0 or +10+(-6) These are the two ways which he mentioned at 3:30
neither 6 or 10 is final or initial.

Consider a soot particle of mass 𝑚𝑠𝑜𝑜𝑡 = 1.0 𝑥 10−12 𝑘𝑔 that travels upward in a smokestack and a charge of 𝑞𝑠𝑜𝑜𝑡 = 1.1 𝑥 10−17𝐶. Assume the electric field in the scrubber is produced by two parallel, square plates of width 𝐿 = 1.0 𝑚 and separation 𝑑 = 0.010 𝑚, with charges ±𝑄.   What must be the value of the electric field between the plates so that the force on the soot particle is equal to the weight of the particle? (A real scrubber would use a collection of many pairs of such plates in parallel)  What charge Q on the scrubber’s plates is required to produce the electric field in part (a)?
